Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Role Of Ritual In Household And Societal Solidarity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Jessica MacLellan, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of Arizona, will investigate the role of household rituals in the development of ancient Maya civilization. This project will provide empirical evidence to address broad questions about the roles of households and ritual in social and political change around the world, particularly in non-Western societies. Many scholars have shown that public rituals are key to the integration of communities and the emergence of kingship in early states. Some argue that such rituals are based on pre-existing domestic practices, but in the case of the earliest Maya communities, the nature of the relationship between domestic and public remains unclear. MacLellan's research will illuminate the social processes involved in the transition to a sedentary, agriculture-based lifestyle and in the subsequent emergence of a complex civilization. Related studies in the Maya area have focused on smaller sites, later time periods, and other regions, and therefore on different social processes. MacLellan's work will provide a new, complementary perspective on the role of household activities in the development of socio-political hierarchies.

MacLellan's research is part of the Ceibal-Petexbat√∫n Archaeological Project, an international collaboration directed by Dr. Takeshi Inomata and Dr. Daniela Triadan, also of the University of Arizona. The site of Ceibal, in Guatemala, was founded as a public ceremonial center surprisingly early - around the time sedentary villages and ceramics began to appear in the Maya lowlands (about 1000 BC). Ceibal therefore presents a rare opportunity to investigate how changes in ritual practices relate to important socio-political transformations, beginning around the transition to agriculture. MacLellan has conducted preliminary investigations at the Karinel Group, an early residential area. Through further, carefully targeted excavations at the Karinel Group and subsequent laboratory analyses, MacLellan will evaluate three specific questions in order to determine how shifts in household ritual affected the broader society at Ceibal: 1) When did people at Ceibal began living in permanent, formal groups of structures, and did a more mobile lifestyle continue after the site's public plaza was constructed?; 2) During which time periods did domestic rituals resemble public rituals conducted in the Central Plaza?; and 3) Did domestic rituals involving the bones of ancestors predate and facilitate the development of socio-political hierarchies? MacLellan will establish a clear, refined chronology of the Karinel Group through ceramic analysis and radiocarbon dating in order to answer these questions. This chronology will serve as important comparative data for other Mesoamerican archaeologists. The Ceibal project will employ many local Maya and Hispanic laborers. Through interactions with nearby communities, the researchers will discourage looting, deforestation, and other destructive activities at archaeological sites in the region. The project will also train several Guatemalan students in field and laboratory methods, thereby shaping and supporting the next generation of Guatemalan archaeologists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From artwork, architecture, and inscriptions, we know that the ancient Maya kings relied on public ceremonies to bring their communities together during the Classic period. However, smaller-scale rituals were also carried out at the household level. What role did household rituals play in the origins of complex societies like that of the Maya? Some Mayanists have argued that the Classic period spectacles developed out of earlier, domestic practices. Based on its very early public plaza, dating to 950 BC, the site of Ceibal, in Guatemala, is an ideal place to study the interplay of household and public rituals around the time the Maya became sedentary, started relying on intensive maize agriculture, and began to use pottery. At the Karinel Group, an early residential area where the bedrock is located relatively near the ground surface, we were able to carry out wide excavations of early living surfaces, structures, and deposits. By carefully recording the stratigraphy, analyzing the artifacts recovered, and radiocarbon dating charcoal samples, we established a chronology for the group.

We found that the social processes that took place at early Ceibal were different from those seen at other early Maya sites in Belize. At Ceibal, permanent, formal house platforms were not constructed until about 800 BC, suggesting that part of the site’s population maintained a semi-mobile lifestyle long after the monumental public plaza was constructed. This finding supports other studies worldwide that suggest egalitarian, mobile groups are capable of monumental construction. We found that household rituals and public rituals in the plaza had little in common until about 400 BC, contradicting the hypothesis that early elites co-opted existing domestic rites in order to gain power. While public ceremonies involved caching objects along the centerline of the plaza, early households carried out rituals on circular platforms within in their patios, possibly using ceramic figurines. These performances may have created a group identity, distinguishing one household from the others and tying the group to its place in the landscape. Signs of elite status are present at the Karinel Group by 500 BC, before domestic practices began to resemble those seen in the plaza. Around 400 BC, circular platforms and figurines disappeared, and the caching of objects began to take place in domestic groups. This centralization of ritual practices may have paved the way for the emergence of the first Maya kings. Surprisingly, we found no evidence of the ancestor veneration rituals that are supposed to have led to property ownership and the rise of social and political inequality at village sites in Belize. We conclude that a single model for the origins of Maya civilization cannot be applied across the entire Maya region.

This project has resulted in the training of several Guatemalan students who represent the future of professional archaeology in Guatemala. It has provided employment to many people in the area around Ceibal. In addition, we have begun a public outreach project to bring information about archaeology, the ancient Maya, and Ceibal to schools in the nearby Q’eqchi’ Maya descendent community of Las Pozas. Through this activity, we encourage the younger generation to find ways their community can benefit from local cultural resources while protecting archaeological sites from destruction. Our results have been presented in English and Spanish at multiple conferences. Reports have been submitted to the Institute of Anthropology and History in Guatemala. Preliminary work resulted in two peer-reviewed journal articles and a short, online, open-access article. Future journal articles, book chapters, and a dissertation are in progress.
